facts.text: Petitioners took on lease the ground floor portion of property in Ward No. V, Nondh No. 1088 of Surat.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners in both these applications have taken on lease the ground floor portion of property in Ward No. V. Nondh No. 1088 of Surat.

facts.text: Respondent became owner by purchasing the property from previous owner by registered sale deed dated September 18, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent became the owner of the said property by purchasing it from the previous owner by a registered sale deed dated September 18, 1958.

facts.text: Petitioners were tenants prior to respondent's purchase and continued as his tenants using premises for business.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners who were the tenants of the premises even prior to the date of purchase by the respondent, have continued to be his tenants and they are using the premises for their business purposes.

facts.text: Respondent filed civil suit No. 144 of 1967 on February 12, 1967 in court of Third Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division, Surat for evicting petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent landlord filed on February 12, 1967 a civil suit No. 144 of 1967 in the court of the Third Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division, Surat for evicting the petitioners.

facts.text: Landlord alleged petitioners had not paid rent for over six months and not complied with notice under Section 12 of Bombay Rent Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to the landlord the petitioners had not paid the rent for a period of over six months and had also not complied with the notice issued under Section 12 of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act 1947 (Act 57 of 1947) hereinafter called the Bombay Rent Act.

facts.text: Respondent terminated tenancy of petitioners by notice dated November 24, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had alleged that he had terminated the tenancy of the petitioners by notice dated November 24, 1966.

facts.text: Respondent sought eviction on grounds of default in payment of rent and premises required for bona fide personal use and occupation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sought eviction of the petitioners on two grounds namely, 1 default in payment of rent, and 2 premises being required for bonafide personal use and occupation.

facts.text: Petitioners contested suit, denied arrears, pleaded raised dispute on standard rent within time, and landlord's requirement not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners contested the suit on various grounds and denied that they were in arrears and pleaded that they had raised a dispute in respect of the standard rent within the time allowed by law They also contended that the landlords requirements for use of occupation-was not bonafide.

facts.text: Trial court and appellate court (Extra Assistant Judge, Surat) rejected respondent's plea for bona fide personal use.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial court as well as the appellate Court the Extra Assistant Judge, surat, have concurrently rejected the plea of the respondent that he required the premises bonafide for personal use.

facts.text: Both courts held petitioners did not raise dispute about standard rent within one month of suit notice.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts held that the petitioners have not raised any dispute about the standard rent within one month of service of suit notice either by preferring a standard rent application or by sending, a reply to the, suit notice raising such a dispute.

facts.text: Both lower courts ordered eviction under Section 12(3)(a) of Bombay Rent Act for non-payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: On this basis both the courts held that the respondent-plaintiff is entitled to recover possession of the premises on the ground of, non payment of rent under Section 12 (3) (a) of the Bombay Rent Act and accordingly passed an order directing eviction of the petitioners from the suit, premises.

facts.text: Petitioners filed Civil Revision Application No. 1353 of 1970 before Gujarat High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners filed Civil, Revision Application No. 1353 of 1970 before the Gujarat High. Court challenging the decision of the two subordinate courts ordering their eviction.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court summarily rejected CRP No. 1353/1970 on December 22, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court summarily rejected the said application by its order dated December 22, 1970.

facts.text: Petitioners filed Special Leave Petition No. 342 of 1971 against Gujarat HC decision.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners filed Special Leave Petition No. 342 of 1971 seeking special leave to appeal against the decision of the Gujarat High- Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on February 15, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the conflict between the Bombay and Gujarat High Courts regarding the interpretation of the above section, this Court granted special leave by its order dated February 15, 1971.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted ex parte stay pending notice of motion.

anchor.surface_text: This Court further granted exparte stay pending disposal of the notice of motion, which was made returnable within three weeks.

facts.text: Petitioners filed CMP No. 854 of 1971 for stay of Gujarat HC order.

anchor.surface_text: Along with the special leave petition the petitioners have filed C. M. P. No. 854 of 1971 praying for the stay of operation of the order of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 1353 of 1970.

facts.text: Petitioners filed CMP No. 2282 of 1971 to amend CMP 854.

anchor.surface_text: In order to, clarify the Prayers made in C.M. P. No. 854 of 1971, the petitioners have filed C. M. P. No, 2282 of 1971 requesting permission to amend their original application C. M. P. No 854 of 1971.

facts.text: Respondent filed counter-affidavit seeking revocation of special leave and dissolution of stay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent entered appearance and filed his counter- affidavit in C. M. P. No. 854 of 1971. In the counter- affidavit the respondent has made two prayers, namely, 1 to revoke the special leave granted to the petitioners and 2 to dissolve the order of stay granted- exparte.

facts.text: Respondent alleged petitioners misled Supreme Court by not disclosing Full Bench Bombay HC judgment was not placed before Gujarat HC.

anchor.surface_text: The bone of contention in this regard as pointed out by Mr, N. Shroff, learned counsel for the respondent is that the Full Bench decision of the Bombay High Court, which is stated to be in direct conflict with the decision of the Gujarat High Court has never been placed before the Gujarat High Court when it dismissed in limine C. R. P. No. 1353 of 1970.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no untrue statement or suppression by petitioners warranting revocation of special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Having due regard to the principles laid down above and applying them to the case on hand, we are of the, opinion that the request of the respondent for revoking special leave granted has to be rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed CMP 2282/1971 and amended CMP 854/1971.

anchor.surface_text: The C. M. Ps. Nos. 2282 of 1971 is allowed and the prayer in C. M. P. No. 854 of 1961 will stand suitably amended.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted stay of dispossession pending appeal with conditions on rent deposits.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the stay application, it is ordered that there will be a stay of dispossession of the petitioners from the premises pending disposal of the appeal by this Court provided, 1 the petitioners deposit in the trial court within one month from today the entire arrears of rent and 2 the petitioners deposit in the trial court rent for every month on or before the 10th of the succeeding month.

facts.text: Petitioners undertook to deliver possession within three months if appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It is also recorded that Mr. S. T. Desai, learned counsel for the petitioners, has undertaken on behalf of the firm and its partners that they will deliver possession of the premises within three months from the date of judgment in the appeal, in case the appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: There is conflict between Bombay HC Full Bench and Gujarat HC on interpretation of Section 12(3)(a) Bombay Rent Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has been further stated that there is a direct conflict regarding the interpretation of this section between the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court and the Gujarat High Court.

facts.text: Bombay HC held Sec 12(3)(a) not applicable even if standard rent dispute raised in written statement.

anchor.surface_text: According to the petitioners, the Bombay High Court has held that the matter will not fall under. Section 12 (3) (a) even in those cases where a dispute in respect of standard rent has been raised in the written statement.

facts.text: Full Bench Bombay HC decision in Special Civil Application No. 718/1968 dated August 17, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: That the High Court ought to have examined the aspect as to whether in view of the judgment of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 718 of 1968 decided on 17th August, 1970.

facts.text: Gujarat HC decision followed by lower courts: Chunilal Shivlal Chimanlal Nagindas.

anchor.surface_text: The contrary view taken by the Gujarat High Court is the one reported in Chunilal Shivlal Chimanlal Nagindas , which has been followed by the two subordinate courts.

issues.text: Whether Section 12(3)(a) of the Bombay Rent Act entitles the landlord to eviction when the tenant has not raised a dispute about standard rent within one month of service of suit notice, even if raised in the written statement, in view of conflict between Bombay High Court Full Bench and Gujarat High Court

anchor.surface_text: In the special leave petition it has been stated that the appeal raises important question of law relating to the scope ,and applicability of Section 12  33   a  of the Bombay Rent Act, which applies in all material particular to both the States of Maharashtra and Gujarat. It has been further stated that there is a direct conflict regarding the interpretation of this section between the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court and the Gujarat High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We will deal with the prayers for grant of stay of dispossession after disposal of the plea raised by the respondent that the Special leave granted by this Court should be revoked. Assuming it is so, in our opinion, it cannot be stated that there is any misstatement or untrue averment contained in these grounds.

holdings.text: The request of the respondent for revoking special leave granted has to be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Having due regard to the principles laid down above and applying them to the case on hand, we are of the, opinion that the request of the respondent for revoking special leave granted has to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied precedents on Art. 136 discretion, clean hands doctrine, and revocation for untrue statements or suppression to facts; found no untrue averment or suppression of material facts.

holdings.text: There has been no false or untrue averment on material facts made by the petitioners for the purpose of misleading this Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are also satisfied that there has been no false or untrue averment on material facts made by the petitioners for the purpose of misleading this Court. Paragraph No. 2 of the special leave petition refers to the conflict between the Gujarat and- Bombay High Courts

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements in SLP para 2 and grounds 2,3,16 are pure legal contentions on High Court conflict, not material facts requiring disclosure of whether cited below.

holdings.text: What is stated in paragraph No. 2 of the special leave petition is a pure statement of the legal position and factually it is correct.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph No. 2 of the special leave petition refers to the conflict between the Gujarat and- Bombay High Courts with regard to the scope and applicability of Section 12  3   a  of the Bombay Rent Act. The contrary view taken by the Gujarat High Court is the one reported in Chunilal Shivlal Chimanlal Nagindas  3 , which has been followed by the two subordinate courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 2 correctly states existence of conflict between Bombay HC Full Bench and Gujarat HC on Sec 12(3)(a), as followed by lower courts.

holdings.text: Grounds Nos. 2, 3 and 16 are purely legal contentions and contain no misstatement or untrue averment.

anchor.surface_text: We have also referred to the grounds Nos. 2, 3 and 16 which are purely legal contentions. The contention of Mr. Shroff, learned counsel for respondent is that a reading of these grounds gives the impression that the attention of the Gujarat High Court was drawn to the Full Bench decision of the Bombay High Court when the Civil Revision Petition was disposed of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming impression given that decision was cited below, grounds are legal contentions challenging HC judgment, not factual averments.

holdings.text: None of the statements in the special leave petition relied on can be considered to be untrue or false statements on material facts or matters of importance.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that none of the statements in the special leave petition relied on by Mr. Shroff can be considered to be untrue or false statements on material facts or matters of importance. Therefore, the prayer of the respondent for revoking the special leave granted will have to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal contentions on High Court conflict permissible without specifying if contrary decision cited below; analogy to appealing single judge ignoring division bench.

holdings.text: C.M.P. No. 2282 of 1971 is allowed and the prayer in C.M.P. No. 854 of 1971 stands suitably amended.

anchor.surface_text: The C. M. Ps. Nos. 2282 of 1971 is allowed and the prayer in C. M. P. No. 854 of 1961 will stand suitably amended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permitted amendment to clarify stay prayer for dispossession pending appeal.

holdings.text: There will be a stay of dispossession of the petitioners from the premises pending disposal of the appeal subject to deposit of arrears and monthly rents.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the stay application, it is ordered that there will be a stay of dispossession of the petitioners from the premises pending disposal of the appeal by this Court provided,  1  the petitioners deposit in the trial court within one month from today the entire arrears of rent and  2  the petitioners deposit in the trial court rent for every month on or before the 10th of the succeeding month.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditional stay after rejecting revocation; balance interests with deposit conditions and liberty to withdraw.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph No. 2 of the special leave petition refers to the conflict between the Gujarat and- Bombay High Courts with regard to the scope and applicability of Section 12  3   a  of the Bombay Rent Act. The contrary view taken by the Gujarat High Court is the one reported in Chunilal Shivlal Chimanlal Nagindas  3 , which has been followed by the two subordinate courts.

Therefore, the prayer of the respondent for revoking the special leave granted will have to be rejected. The C. M. Ps. Nos. 2282 of 1971 is allowed and the prayer in C. M. P. anchor.surface_text: We have also referred to the grounds Nos. 2, 3 and 16 which are purely legal contentions. The contention of Mr. Shroff, learned counsel for respondent is that a reading of these grounds gives the impression that the attention of the Gujarat High Court was drawn to the Full Bench decision of the Bombay High Court when the Civil Revision Petition was disposed of.

Therefore, the prayer of the respondent for revoking the special leave granted will have to be rejected. The C. M. Ps. Nos. 2282 of 1971 is allowed and the prayer in C. M. P. No. 854 of 1961 will stand suitably amended.
